bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Hugo Ascanio, April 30, 1941

div1.p: Hench thanks Ascanio for the hospitality extended to him during his visit to the Military Hospital. Copies of the "Proceedings of the Mayo Clinic Staff Meetings" will be sent to him and his friends regularly.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Hugo Ascanio, April 30, 1941
div1.opener:
April 30, 1941
Dr. Hugo Ascanio
Hospital Militar “Dr. Aristides Agramonte”
Ciudad Militar
Havana, Cuba
My dear Doctor Ascanio:
div1.p:
I just returned home after continuing my vacation in Florida
and attending a medical meeting in Boston. It was indeed a great pleasure to
meet you and your colleagues in the Military Hospital, and you were very kind
to take me around and help me so much. It is with pleasure that I have asked
the editor of the Proceedings of the Mayo Clinic Staff Meetings to send you
these Proceedings regularly. I am also sending it to your friends on the list
which you gave me.

I wonder if you have been able to get for me an actual copy of
the airplane view of the Military Hospital which was published in the Revista de
la Sanidad Militar, Ano II, No. 2, April, May, June, 1938. I believe the editor
of this journal or the man in the publicity department told me he would get one
for me. If at all possible, I should like to have two glossy prints, one for my
files and one to use for publication. We will of course give credit to the Revista.
You were also kind enough to tell me that you would get a small photograph of
the monument. I believe it was either the Illinois or the Indiana monument. If
possible, I should like to have glossy prints of this too. Any expense connected
with this I will be delighted to defray. Is there any possibility that I could
have this within a fairly short time?

I am notifying Dr. A. Perez Ara that he is to receive the Pro-
ceedings. I am also thanking him for the airplane photographs which he sent me.
If you are unable to get the airplane view from the Revista for me, I should like
to get glossy prints from Dr. Ara. However, the photograph in the Revista par-
ticularly pleases me because it shows the railroad track and the tree across the
track, where the false Camp Lazear was situated. Dr. Ara's photographs do not
show this.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
